soc.client

Class Sounds

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.client.Sounds

  • public class Sounds
extends java.lang.Object
    Utility class for creating and playing basic synthesized sounds with the javax.sound.sampled package.

    Usage:

    Either generate and play a tone using chime(int, int, double) or tone(int, int, double), or generate one using genChime(int, int, double) or genTone(int, int, double) to be played later with playPCMBytes(byte[]).

    To concatenate sequentially generated tones or chimes in a single buffer, make a buffer of length bufferLen(int) and then call genChime(int, int, double, byte[], int, boolean) and/or genTone(int, int, double, byte[], int) to fill it.

    Generating tones ahead of time can help with latency, instead of allocating a buffer each time a sound is played.

    Some Java versions on some platforms may have trouble reliably playing a sample longer than 1000ms.

    Since:
    1.2.00
    Author:
    Jeremy D Monin <jeremy@nand.net>

    • Method Detail

      • bufferLen

        public static int bufferLen(int msec)
        Calculate the length of a mono 16-bit PCM byte buffer, at SAMPLE_RATE_HZ, to store msec milliseconds.
        Parameters:
        msec - Duration in milliseconds
        Returns:
        Buffer length required to store msec milliseconds; is also the number of samples

      • genChime

        public static int genChime(int hz,
                           int msec,
                           double vol,
                           byte[] buf,
                           int i0,
                           boolean overlay)
                    throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                           java.lang.NullPointerException
        Generate a chime, with volume fading out to 0, into an existing buffer.
        Parameters:
        hz - Tone in Hertz (recommended max is half of SAMPLE_RATE_HZ)
        msec - Duration in milliseconds
        vol - Volume (max is 1.0)
        buf - An existing little-endian mono 16-bit PCM buffer into which to generate the chime. Use bufferLen(int) to calculate the required length.
        i0 - Starting position (index) to use within buf
        overlay - If true, combine amplitude of the new chime with what's in the buffer. Total volume is additive. Does not clip or check for overflow.
        Returns:
        1 past the ending position (index) used within buf; the next generate call can use this value for its i0
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if buf isn't long enough, given msec and i0
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if buf is null
        See Also:
        genChime(int, int, double)

      • genChime

        public static byte[] genChime(int hz,
                              int msec,
                              double vol)
                       throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Generate a chime, with volume fading out to 0. For buffer format details see genChime(int, int, double, byte[], int, boolean).
        Parameters:
        hz - Tone in Hertz (recommended max is half of SAMPLE_RATE_HZ)
        msec - Duration in milliseconds (max is 1000)
        vol - Volume (max is 1.0)
        Returns:
        a PCM buffer containing the generated chime, suitable for playPCMBytes(byte[])
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if msec > 1000
        See Also:
        genChime(int, int, double, byte[], int, boolean)

      • chime

        public static void chime(int hz,
                         int msec,
                         double vol)
                  throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                         javax.sound.sampled.LineUnavailableException
        Generate and play a chime, with volume fading out to 0.
        Parameters:
        hz - Tone in Hertz (recommended max is half of SAMPLE_RATE_HZ)
        msec - Duration in milliseconds (max is 1000)
        vol - Volume (max is 1.0)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if msec > 1000
        javax.sound.sampled.LineUnavailableException - if the line resource can't be opened

      • genTone

        public static int genTone(int hz,
                          int msec,
                          double vol,
                          byte[] buf,
                          int i0)
                   throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                          java.lang.NullPointerException
        Generate a constant tone into an existing buffer.

        Based on https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23096533/how-to-play-a-sound-with-a-given-sample-rate-in-java from RÃ©al Gagnon's code at http://www.rgagnon.com/javadetails/java-0499.html: optimized, decoupled from 8000Hz fixed sampling rate, separated generation from playback, used 16 bits, implemented generation into existing buffer.

        Parameters:
        hz - Tone in Hertz (recommended max is half of SAMPLE_RATE_HZ)
        msec - Duration in milliseconds
        vol - Volume (max is 1.0)
        buf - An existing little-endian mono 16-bit PCM buffer into which to generate the tone. Use bufferLen(int) to calculate the required length.
        i0 - Starting position (index) to use within buf
        Returns:
        1 past the ending position (index) used within buf; the next generate call can use this value for its i0
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if buf isn't long enough, given msec and i0
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if buf is null
        See Also:
        genTone(int, int, double)

      • genTone

        public static byte[] genTone(int hz,
                             int msec,
                             double vol)
                      throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Generate a constant tone into a new PCM buffer. For buffer format details see genTone(int, int, double, byte[], int).
        Parameters:
        hz - Tone in Hertz (recommended max is half of SAMPLE_RATE_HZ)
        msec - Duration in milliseconds (max is 1000)
        vol - Volume (max is 1.0)
        Returns:
        A sound byte buffer, suitable for playPCMBytes(byte[])
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if msec > 1000
        See Also:
        genTone(int, int, double, byte[], int)

      • tone

        public static void tone(int hz,
                        int msec,
                        double vol)
                 throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                        javax.sound.sampled.LineUnavailableException
        Generate and play a constant tone.
        Parameters:
        hz - Tone in Hertz (recommended max is half of SAMPLE_RATE_HZ)
        msec - Duration in milliseconds (max is 1000)
        vol - Volume (max is 1.0)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if msec > 1000
        javax.sound.sampled.LineUnavailableException - if the line resource can't be opened

      • playPCMBytes

        public static void playPCMBytes(byte[] buf)
                         throws javax.sound.sampled.LineUnavailableException
        Play a sound byte buffer, such as that generated by genTone(int, int, double) or genChime(int, int, double).
        Parameters:
        buf - Buffer to play; PCM little-endian mono 16-bit signed, at SAMPLE_RATE_HZ
        Throws:
        javax.sound.sampled.LineUnavailableException - if the line resource can't be opened
